But someone (human!) has to write that assertion or pos=
tcondition using a mental model of how the system ought to behave. The comp=
uter won't generate it for you.

>Another way to do is to automatically 
>d=
etect program anomalies. This is actually a purpose of my project. 

I don'=
t understand you: how does one automatically detect a program anomaly. How =
does one decide what constitutes an anomaly in the first place? Surely the =
computer does not: it does not have the requisite ability to judge whether =
an event is anomalous.

I suppose there are some obvious kinds of anomaly, =
such as a process aborting unexpectedly, but otherwise, what else is there =
that a computer could determine on its own? Even so, sometimes a process *s=
hould* abort.

>Running the program with a large set of test case. For the =
execution 
>to construct possible program invariant. If some test case caus=
e the 
>execution violates the deduced program invariant, a program bug mig=
ht 
>be found. That's why I want a tool for automatically generating test 
=
>case. 

How does running a suite of tests -- of any size -- establish a pr=
ogram invariant? Even if it does, how meaningful can that invariant be?

I =
think you're using the term "test case" to refer to something other than we=
 expect. We define a "test case", loosely, as code that executes some part =
of a program then compares its output with some known expected result. [Tes=
t cases need not be automatic, but this is a JUnit group after all.] The te=
st case is said to pass if the output matches the expected result and fails=
 otherwise. The key part of this definition is the expected result: how can=
 a computer determine the expected result? It seems to me that only a human=
 can do that. This is a consequence of the fact that computers only do what=
 we tell them to do.

It sounds to me like you're just looking to generate =
random blocks of code that exercise different code paths in a program, with=
 the goal of covering an ever-increasing portion of the possible execution =
paths. Those are not test cases -- at least not by our well-established and=
 widely-accepted definition. Those are just blocks of code. Is that what yo=
u're trying to do? 

That is something that a computer could be capable of:=
 analyzing source code to generate legal (that is to say, compilable) block=
s of code that call the program or its objects. A computer may even be capa=
ble of using elementary heuristics to generate "somewhat meaningful" blocks=
 of code, by repeatedly invoking methods on the same object, for example. T=
he resulting code, however, does nothing to answer the question, "Does the =
program behave as expected?" That is the question that we care about when w=
e write tests.

The notion of using these generated blocks of code to estab=
lish probable system invariants is interesting, but my uninformed guess is =
that it is extremely unlikely to discover a meaningful system invariant wit=
hout human guidance. The computer is likely incapable of identifying candid=
ates to be meaningful invariants, let alone verify that they are actually i=
nvariant. [I say "unlikely" rather than impossible because it may be a mere=
 limit of computing power, but I doubt it. Never say 'never'.]

It's an int=
eresting topic, but it sounds impossible within the Turing Machine model of=
 computing. Not knowing any other models of computing in common use (in oth=
er words, for which you can find a functioning computer), I can't help you =
further on this. Good luck.

Looking back, that reads as awfully negative; =
but my reasoning looks pretty solid. I'm sorry if this throws cold water on=
 a research project. Of course, if you think you can do it, you won't liste=
n to me, anyway. :)
